Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator and his colleagues will study selected topics in high-dimensional regression, classification and hypothesis testing. Specifically, these include a sparse factor model for high-dimensional regression and survival analysis, large scale interaction testing with applications to genomics, the computational algorithms for the fused lasso, and a research monograph on L1-constrained (Lasso) methods in statistics.

This work will help scientists working in biotech and other areas, who generate large scale datasets, to interpret and uncover the important patterns in their data. This should help scientists and doctors to discover the biological bases of many diseases, and improve prognosis and treatment selection for patients.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this age of big data and technology, statistical tools for extracting knowledge from the data are essential. Many such tools exist and are being applied to medical diagnosis, bioinformatics and genetic modeling, chemical process control, shape, handwriting, speech and face recognition,financial modeling, and a wide range of other important practical problems. 

 

In this research I have developed  new statistical methods for the analysis of big datasets, for use in science and industry. I have also written a monograph summarizing many  state-of-the-art methods and trained a number of PhD students in this area. This work could have impact in the field of Statistics and more broadly, for example in science, medicine and finance. The tools that Ihave developed (with students and collaborators) are all made available in open-source software, for use by researchers and others working in diverse areas of science and industry. Various software companies have also built new products on top of our programs, in enable their application to extremely large datasets, such as those obtained from online ad clicks and other  consumer applications.  This new products use distributed , parallel, and cloud computing to tackle problems that are too large to fit into the memory of a single computer.
